themes.title: VALUE REDEFINITION
themes.description:
**Nature as Primary Value**
- Circular economy measured in kilos (material flows) not currency
- Balance between human and nature values currently imbalanced
- Nature value becoming scarce, driving circular economy importance
- Moving from meaningless growth to sustainable development

themes.title: TRUST & COLLABORATION
themes.description:
**Nordic Cultural Assets**
- Trust as foundational infrastructure (especially in Arctic contexts)
- Collaboration, design thinking, technology as Nordic strengths
- Pre-competitive frameworks enabling business collaboration
- Sense of responsibility remaining strong in Nordic societies

**Examples:**
- Denmark's Circular Furniture Network: 30 competing brands collaborating
- Voluntary Sector Collaboration on Textiles
- Nordic Circular Investments project (Finland, Sweden, Norway)

themes.title: ADAPTABILITY OVER SCALE
themes.description:
**Rethinking Growth Models**
- Adaptable models more appropriate than rigid scalable models
- Context matters: rural vs urban, local vs global
- Arctic strengths: reuse, resource respect, local self-reliance
- 28 million Nordic market as platform, not template

themes.title: POLITICAL GAP
themes.description:
**Ambition vs. Implementation**
- Paper commitments to sustainability vs. short-term economic focus
- Circular strategies broad, non-binding, politically fragile
- EU leadership (Circular Economy Commissioner) vs. national lag
- Need for alignment between national politics and EU targets

**Denmark Exception:**
- National action plan on textiles in Fiscal Act
- Government prioritizing previously neglected sectors
- Movement from rhetoric to resource allocation

themes.title: INVESTMENT BARRIERS
themes.description:
**Why Circular Is "Too Risky"**
- Longer timelines required for circular business models
- Physical infrastructure needs (factories, logistics)
- Market education necessary
- Multi-stakeholder collaboration networks take time to build

**Solutions Needed:**
- Hybrid public-private investment models
- KPIs for measuring circular impact
- Best practice libraries
- Lower risk through collaborative funding

themes.title: YOUTH & SYSTEM CHANGE
themes.description:
**Three Levels of Circular Economy**
1. **Micro**: Individual/company practices
2. **Economy-wide**: Percentage circular (currently 4% globally)
3. **System**: Macroeconomic design, incentives, decision-making

**Youth Strategies:**
- **Outside pressure**: Direct action (e.g., NaturUngdom Norway blocking oil field)
- **Inside participation**: Advisory boards (e.g., Generation 2030 Finland)
- 18 organizations in Regeneration 2030 network across Nordic-Baltic region

**Demands:**
1. Invite organized youth groups into decision rooms
2. Support street activism
3. Don't criminalize climate action

---

themes.title: TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE
themes.description:
**Arctic Circular Wisdom**
- Generations of resourcefulness: nothing wasted
- Every part of catch has purpose
- Adaptive, practical, community-driven approaches
- Cultural foundation informing modern innovation
- Self-sufficiency strategies rooted in local knowledge

themes.title: INDUSTRIAL SYMBIOSIS
themes.description:
**Nature's Model for Economy**
- Organizing industries like ecosystems (no waste)
- Regional symbiosis across Nordic-Arctic
- Supply chain collaboration over silos
- Turning geographic remoteness into advantage

**Examples:**
- Circular Furniture Network pre-competitive repair systems
- Textile transition groups bridging sectors
- Construction sector transformative approaches

themes.title: BALTIC-NORDIC EXPANSION
themes.description:
**The New Nordics**
- Baltic Circular Hotspot established 2024
- First transition group in textiles forming
- Win-win: Nordic experience + Baltic fresh perspectives
- Baltics as sandbox/testbed for solutions before scaling
- Latvia Circularity Report: adaptable index for municipalities

themes.title: UNLEARNING & RESKILLING
themes.description:
**Knowledge Infrastructure**
- 250-year-old linear economy embedded in thinking
- "Fish don't know what water is" - need to see the system
- Reskilling all generations, not just youth
- Human and knowledge infrastructure as critical as physical
- Moving from linear to circular mindset

**Key Transitions Needed:**
- Short-term â†’ Long-term perspective
- Linear â†’ Circular thinking
- Quantity â†’ Quality of life
- Physical â†’ Digital integration
- Rural â†” Urban connection

quotes.text: The real infrastructure in Greenland is trust, I would say. Not the roads, not the... Yeah, trust is the real infrastructure in Greenland. Without it, we don't have any.
quotes.speaker: Edvard Lybert MÃ¸rk

quotes.text: If you just take away three things from what my generation would need in order to be involved in the planning of our future, I would say: **Invite us into the room, support us on the streets, and don't jail us.**
quotes.speaker: Keira Dignan

quotes.text: We live in a 250-year-old linear economy. I used to say the fish don't know what water is. So my generation really needsâ€”it's a big task to unlearn what we have learned and grew up in.
quotes.speaker: Cathrine Barth
quotes.affiliation: Natural State Norway / Nordic Circular Hotspot

quotes.text: If there's one key takeaway that we will listen throughout the day and also tomorrow, it's the super skill that we can leverage: **symbiosis**. It is actually another word for how nature works. We don't have waste in nature, but how do we organize our industries and societies for industrial symbiosis and regional symbiosis? This is maybe one of the unfair advantages we have.
quotes.speaker: Cathrine Barth
quotes.affiliation: Natural State Norway / Nordic Circular Hotspot

quotes.text: Circular Economy goes on **kilos, not krona or dollars**. It really explains the natural resources in our systems. And that is why this is now coming.
quotes.speaker: Einar Kleppe Holthe

quotes.text: Greenlandic tradition in hunting and local food production are built on generations of practical experience. They reflect careful use of resources where **nothing is wasted and every part of the catch has a purpose**. This cultural foundation continues to inform how we develop food systems today, connecting tradition with modern opportunities for innovation.
quotes.speaker: Peter Borg

quotes.text: The Nordics share on paper an ambition to become the most sustainable region by 2030. In practice, however, I see from my perspective, mostly short-term economic concerns being addressed. We do have an excellent environment for testbedding circular transition in the Nordics. But for that to happen, **national politics need to, at the very least, align with already set targets and the ambitions of the European Union.**
quotes.speaker: Michel Bajuk

quotes.text: With circular investments we probably need **new types of investment models** which bring public investments and private investments together so that we can also lower the risk that private investors are currently seeing in circular investments.
quotes.speaker: Alisa Mick

quotes.text: What I would like us to push is to think about the third level of circular economy, which is the **system level**. How is our economy designed? How is it functioning? What are the incentives? Who gets to make the decisions? These sort of macroeconomic systems end up defining the success or failure of sustainable economic models.
quotes.speaker: Keira Dignan

quotes.text: I think this is the most important part of infrastructure. It's the **human and knowledge infrastructure**. How do we reskill our next generation and any generation time to come so we can scale faster into an economy that is in balance with the nature systems?
quotes.speaker: Cathrine Barth
quotes.affiliation: Natural State Norway / Nordic Circular Hotspot

themes.title: 100% UTILIZATION PHILOSOPHY
themes.description:
**From Waste to Value**
- Iceland went from 45% to 90%+ fish utilization
- Every part used: fillets, heads, skins, bones, guts, blood
- Applications: food, textiles, cosmetics, biotech, biomedical
- Economic transformation: $12 â†’ $5,000 per cod

**Transferable Methodology**:
1. Know species and volumes
2. Understand current processing
3. Identify properties of side streams
4. Assess market opportunities
5. Build business cases

**Quote**:
> "Heads, skins, bones, guts, blood are used to create valuable products from food to textiles, cosmetics, biotechnology, and biomedical applications."
> â€” Alexandra Leeper

---

themes.title: CORPORATE TRANSFORMATION JOURNEY
themes.description:
**Royal Greenland Case Study**:
- World's largest cold-water shrimp producer
- 35% of Greenland's GDP
- Ilulissat factory: 12-15K tons shrimp annually
- Challenge: 56-66% historically discarded
- Problem: Shrimp meal factory lost 800K DKK/year

**Transformation Strategy**:
- Shifted from shrimp meal to high-value chitosan
- Partnered through 100% Shrimp project
- Embedded circular thinking in organizational culture
- Leveraged Greenlandic cultural values

**Result**: Loss-making â†’ Profitable operation

**Quote**:
> "It's very important that factories and people who work with this daily take ownership. You can't push projects over people's heads."
> â€” Kristian Ottesen

---

themes.title: SIDE STREAMS AS SUPERFOOD
themes.description:
**Nutritional Superiority**:
- 20x more calcium than fillets
- 10x more zinc
- 5x more collagen
- 2x more iron

**Market Reality**:
- 15% of global seafood wasted at processing stage
- 30-70% becomes low-value products or landfill
- Global demand nearly doubling by 2050
- Solution already exists in current waste

**Hylia's Innovation**:
- Technology transforms side streams to familiar seafood taste/texture
- 8 products in Finnish retail (chilled, frozen, ready meals, canned)
- Awards: UN UNIDO Global Call, Best Business Food Tech

**Quote**:
> "If so much is being lost, we already have the future demand in our hands. We just need to utilize it smarter."
> â€” Michaela LindstrÃ¶m

---

themes.title: CLUSTER ECOSYSTEM AS ENABLER
themes.description:
**Iceland Ocean Cluster**:
- Founded 2011
- 70+ companies in-house
- Sister network: 12 countries
- Projects: 100% Shrimp, Nordic Nexus Network

**Danish Ocean Cluster**:
- Based at Hirtshals port
- Focus: Logistics and transport
- Connects energy, logistics, fishing, technology
- Example: X-ray company + collagen extractor

**ACT Cluster (Northern Norway)**:
- 119 partners
- 8 years trust-building
- Cross-sectoral: process, mining, energy, seafood, manufacturing
- Example: Finnfjord metal + Univ. TromsÃ¸ Arctic algae

**Common Themes**:
- Trust-building takes time
- Connections matter more than ownership
- Right people in right chairs
- Scouting and partnership development
- Long-term perspective required

**Quote**:
> "I don't have many companies from our cluster here. They don't have time for six days for a trip to Nuuk. But I'll bring home potential collaborating partners."
> â€” Monika Poulsen

---

themes.title: LOGISTICS & INFRASTRUCTURE CHALLENGES
themes.description:
**Arctic Reality**:
- Greenland: 37 production sites along coast
- Dispersed geography, extreme conditions
- Critical mass difficult to achieve
- Ice flows prevent simple waste disposal

**Logistics Impact**:
- Quality degrades with each move
- Price follows quality downward
- Volumes essential for viability
- Transport costs eat low margins

**Port Evolution**:
- From ship service to industry developer
- Infrastructure enablers, not business owners
- Planning and policy influence
- Sharing information, not hoarding

**Quote**:
> "Ports' role is changing. We don't want to own everything. We enable and share information."
> â€” Linn Indrestrand

---

themes.title: CROSS-SECTORAL COLLABORATION
themes.description:
**Why It Matters**:
- Solutions lie between sectors, not within
- Companies naturally look inward first
- Cluster role: Connect across boundaries
- Innovation emerges at intersections

**Examples**:
- Metal production + University â†’ Arctic algae for aquaculture
- X-ray tech + Collagen extraction â†’ Pan-European collaboration
- Shrimp processing + Chitosan production â†’ Retail products

**Time Investment**:
- Trust building requires years
- Long-term funding essential
- Partnerships across Arctic and Europe
- Scouting on behalf of companies

**Quote**:
> "Working together across sectors is important because solutions lie in between sectors, not within the sector."
> â€” Monika Poulsen

---

themes.title: CULTURAL FOUNDATION FOR CIRCULARITY
themes.description:
**Greenlandic Tradition**:
- Using everything from a catch: ancient practice
- Cultural way of valuing all parts
- Traditional knowledge informs modern innovation
- Organizational buy-in easier with cultural alignment

**Nordic Advantages**:
- Trust as infrastructure (Session 1 theme returns)
- Collaboration over competition
- Sense of responsibility
- Openness to sharing

**Implementation Insight**:
- Play on cultural values when implementing projects
- Don't fight culture, leverage it
- Ownership comes from alignment with values

**Quote**:
> "It's naturally ingrained in Greenlandic culture to use everything we pull out of the sea. This is something you have to play on when implementing these projects."
> â€” Kristian Ottesen

---

themes.title: BUSINESS CASE FOR COLLABORATION
themes.description:
**How Much Does It Pay?**:
- Reduced operating costs through optimization
- Increased product value through innovation
- Network effects and knowledge sharing
- Accelerated timelines via partnerships
- Strategic value and reputation enhancement

**Cluster ROI**:
- Connections that would take years individually
- Access to funded projects (Nordic Innovation)
- Scouting and partnership development
- Arena for meeting potential partners

**Corporate Benefits**:
- Small startups to massive industrial partners
- Each solving specific tasks
- From unprofitable to profitable operations
- Contribution to national self-sufficiency goals

---

themes.title: ARCTIC AS ADVANTAGE
themes.description:
**Reframing Constraints**:
- Logistics challenges â†’ Force innovation
- Ice and geography â†’ Creative solutions
- Small scale â†’ Adaptability over scale
- Remoteness â†’ Resilient local systems

**Trust Infrastructure**:
- More important than physical infrastructure
- Enables everything else
- Takes time but pays long-term
- Foundation for complex collaborations

**Traditional Knowledge**:
- Ancient circular economy principles
- Nothing wasted philosophy
- Cultural blueprint for modern practice

---

themes.title: NORDIC COLLABORATION MODEL
themes.description:
**Sister Clusters Network**:
- 12 countries connected
- Share methodology, adapt to context
- Constant learning and feedback
- Iceland â†’ Greenland â†’ Denmark â†’ Finland â†’ Norway

**Project Examples**:
- 100% Shrimp (Iceland-Greenland-Denmark-Norway)
- Nordic Nexus Network (water-energy-food nexus)
- Blue Nova Ventures (scaling program)

**Knowledge Transfer**:
- Don't reinvent wheels
- Share core steps and methods
- Adapt to local species and ecosystems
- Build on each other's successes

**Quote**:
> "Partnership and conversation, finding areas of mutual benefit to collaborateâ€”you don't have to meet everyone everywhere all at once. Find connecting pieces that have ripple effects."
> â€” Alexandra Leeper

quotes.text: We lose and waste more than 23 million metric tons of edible quality aquatic food. This is not only environmentally impactful, but economically wasteful.
quotes.speaker: Alexandra Leeper

quotes.text: Atlantic cod has gone from a single fish worth about $12 USD to one that now has a potential value of around $5,000 USD.
quotes.speaker: Alexandra Leeper

quotes.text: We don't need to reinvent the wheels. Those steps and methods are really practically applicable to many other places.
quotes.speaker: Alexandra Leeper

quotes.text: We made all the mistakes you can do in a project like this. We didn't involve the right departments at the right time. But we managed to transform a loss-making factory into a profitable strategy.
quotes.speaker: Kristian S. Ottesen

quotes.text: We have a cultural way of using everything. This is naturally ingrained in Greenlandic culture to use everything we pull out of the sea.
quotes.speaker: Kristian S. Ottesen

quotes.text: Side streams can have 20 times more calcium, 10 times more zinc, 5 times more collagen, and twice as much iron compared to fillets. Imagine eating collagen in your food instead of buying expensive pills.
quotes.speaker: Michaela LindstrÃ¶m

quotes.text: It doesn't matter how good an idea it is. For consumers, it needs to taste good and have good texture. If we want people to eat side streams, they need to resemble familiar seafood.
quotes.speaker: Michaela LindstrÃ¶m

quotes.text: The solutions start with logistics and transport. It's all about volumes. Every time we move resources, quality goes down, and price goes down with it.
quotes.speaker: Linn Indrestrand

quotes.text: Solutions lie between sectors, not within sectors. Our role is connecting companies across sectors to find resources and ideas.
quotes.speaker: Monika Poulsen

themes.description: Anders Ladefoged describing Arctic stakeholders' "almost a sigh" when discussing EU program complexity. Captured frustration and exhaustion perfectly.

themes.title: The Rhetorical Question
themes.description: Patrick Schroeder asking "Can we maintain FPIC? Can we pay a higher price?" then immediately answering "We have to" before Luca jumped in with "Come on!" Moral clarity.

themes.title: Snowy Helsinki
themes.description: Mika Sulkinoja joining from "sort of snowy Helsinki" with "just a tiny bit of snow on ground"â€”humanizing remote participation and grounding policy discussion in weather reality.

themes.title: The 4 Million Nation
themes.description: Cathrine Barth reframing the Arctic as a nation of 4 millionâ€”larger than many EU member states. Simple number, profound reframing.

themes.title: "We Are a Bit Shy"
themes.description: Anders Ladefoged's gentle critique of Nordic political engagement: "We sometimes look too much at getting things right at home." Call to step up on European stage.

themes.title: The Linear Lock-In
themes.description: Cathrine Barth's concern that Arctic could be "left in a linear lock-in and being out on the limbs" while world transitions. Vivid image of being left behind.

themes.title: The Structural Shift
themes.description: Luca De Lorenzo repeating "This is structural" twice for emphasis when discussing resilience value. Banker's certainty that this is permanent, not temporary.

themes.title: Black Mass Paradox
themes.description:
Mika Sulkinoja describing Europe exporting black mass (battery recycling material) while setting recycling targets. Perfect encapsulation of policy incoherence.

themes.title: CIRCULARITY AS TRADITION, NOT TREND
themes.description:
**Cultural Foundation**:
- Nothing wasted in Arctic communities for millennia
- Not environmental consciousnessâ€”survival necessity
- Inuit traditions: every material valued, knowledge shared
- Design, production, and community inseparable

**Greenlandic Mindset**:
- Musk ox wool and sealskin garments
- Seafood side streams fully utilized
- "Waste not, have not, want not" cultural belief
- Resilience through cultural continuity

**The Paradigm Shift**:
- Linear economy: waste is inevitable byproduct
- Circular economy: waste doesn't exist in nature
- Greenlandic reality: waste was never a concept

**Quote**:
> "In Greenland, circularity isn't a trend, it's a tradition and it's the foundation."
> â€” Frederik Thrane

---

themes.title: QUOTA LIMITATIONS AS SUSTAINABILITY DRIVERS
themes.description:
**Grevilliot's Constraint-Based Model**:
- Limited by sustainable musk ox harvest quotas
- Nowhere else to source raw materials globally
- Two-month winter harvesting window only
- Cannot scale beyond ecological limits
- **Result**: Always sold out, but sustainably so

**Business Implications**:
- No discount for volume (price reflects scarcity)
- Cannot serve mass market demand
- Local value retention prioritized over export
- Price point: special occasions, not impulse buys

**Value Creation**:
- Could export raw wool to Canada/US
- Chose local processing to keep value in Greenland
- Beyond hunter payment and processing time
- Community benefit over profit maximization

**The Learning**:
> "If we can make it happen here with limited resources, then it can also be applied in many other places."
> â€” Kristian Ottesen

---

themes.title: COMPLETE TRACEABILITY AND LOCAL PRODUCTION
themes.description:
**Grevilliot's Supply Chain**:
1. Wild animal on mountains (musk ox) or fjord (seal)
2. Hunter harvests for meat
3. Hide/skin sold to Grevilliot
4. Wool removed from hide
5. Shipped for spinning (only external step)
6. Yarn returned to Greenland
7. Knitted/sewn locally
8. Sold with complete story

**Traceability Claim**:
- "Every single material from local hunter"
- "Can't find anything in store where I can't tell you who made it"
- Personal connection to every product
- Maker knows customer (often personally)

**Compare to Conventional Apparel**:
- Grevilliot: 1-degree separation (maker â†’ customer)
- Conventional: Unknown makers, distant factories
- Grevilliot: Complete material journey known
- Conventional: Opaque multi-country supply chains

**Quote**:
> "Your scarf is not just a scarf. It's a bit of a history, a culture, and tradition. And a meal."
> â€” Lise Lotte

---

themes.title: REPAIR AS NATURAL EXTENSION OF MAKING
themes.description:
**The Maker-Repairer Connection**:
- Person who made garment best equipped to repair it
- Customer returns directly to maker
- No third-party repair shops needed
- Relationship-based service

**Why This Works**:
- Maker knows construction intimately
- Materials sourced by maker
- Techniques used by maker
- Pride of craftsmanship drives quality repair

**Contrast with Linear Model**:
- Linear: designer â‰  manufacturer â‰  seller â‰  repairer
- Each handoff loses knowledge
- Repair often impossible or uneconomical
- Product designed for replacement, not longevity

**ESPR's Goal**:
- Codify "right to repair" in regulation
- What regulation mandates, local relationships make natural
- Grevilliot demonstrates repair as embedded practice

**Quote**:
> "This person who made the garment is probably the best in the world to repair it. So you just come back and then they fix it."
> â€” Mia Chemnitz

---

themes.title: WASTE AS STARTING POINT
themes.description:
**The Inuit Philosophy**:
- Hunt for meat (primary purpose)
- Sealskin = clothing survival in Arctic
- Nothing discarded, everything has use
- "Waste" is a foreign concept

**Grevilliot's Foundation**:
- "Founded on waste product"
- But never perceived as waste culturally
- Seal survival enabled Inuit Arctic life
- Modern business built on ancient practice

**Royal Greenland's Evolution**:
- 98% of Greenland exports = seafood
- Industrialization = waste stream creation
- Now: reintroducing pre-industrial practices
- Side streams becoming revenue streams

**The Challenge to Businesses**:
> "I kind of want to challenge companies to start with, okay, we have this waste, let's look at it, and what can we do with it?"
> â€” Mia Chemnitz

**Inversion**:
- Don't minimize waste as afterthought
- Build business on the "waste"
- What linear economy discards = circular foundation

---

themes.title: TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE VS. ACADEMIC PROOF
themes.description:
**The Seal Skin Paradox**:
- No laboratory tests for seal skin performance
- No water pressure ratings
- No breathability metrics
- No standardized certifications

**But...**:
- Millennia of Inuit Arctic survival
- Trusted over tested synthetics
- "I know what I'm going to be wearing" (on ice cap)
- Traditional knowledge = lived proof

**The Epistemological Challenge**:
- Western model: quantifiable metrics required
- Laboratory testing as validation
- Peer-reviewed research
- Standardized certifications

**Indigenous Knowledge Offers**:
- Millennia of experience
- Survival as proof of efficacy
- Cultural transmission of expertise
- Place-based adaptation

**The Question**:
> Can we value knowledge systems that don't produce the documentation our systems demand?

**Quote**:
> "Even the knowledge that might not be academically proven yet, but that has a couple of millennia to prove the value of the outcomes."
> â€” Frederik Thrane

---

themes.title: CULTURAL DECOLONIZATION THROUGH MATERIALS
themes.description:
**The Shift (Past 15 Years)**:
- Then: Canada Goose jackets as "new national suit"
- Now: Reclaiming traditional Greenlandic materials
- Making indigenous materials "fashionable again"

**The Decolonization Movement**:
- Taking back tattoos
- Taking back earrings
- Taking back anorak
- Taking back materials, culture, music

**Why It Matters**:
- Decades of cultural erasure
- Traditional materials seen as "primitive"
- Industrial materials = "progress"
- Dependency on imported goods

**The Reversal**:
- Circular economy discovers traditional materials superior
- More durable, repairable, sustainable, locally sourced
- Indigenous communities reclaim what was dismissed
- Not return to pastâ€”path to sustainable future

**Local Pride**:
- Products Greenlandic people "very proud of"
- Special occasions, custom pieces
- Expression of cultural identity
- Beyond commerceâ€”cultural reclamation

**Quote**:
> "We are taking back our materials, culture, music, everything."
> â€” Mia Chemnitz

---

themes.title: DIGITAL PRODUCT PASSPORT AS COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE
themes.description:
**What is DPP?**:
- QR code connecting physical product to digital data
- "Internet of Things for products"
- Mandatory for EU market access by 2030
- Contains: production info, working conditions, repair, resale, materials

**Why Compliance = Advantage**:
- Fashion/textile sector has no control currently
- "Getting away with it for so long"
- **Control over data reduces costs** (lack of control is expensive)
- Extended Producer Responsibility fees easier to manage

**Storytelling Platform**:
- Not just complianceâ€”communication tool
- "Tell the story of the product"
- More specific product = more specific story
- Grevilliot's stories: history, culture, tradition, meal

**Local Manufacturing Advantage**:
- Ludwig Svensson (Sweden): 137 years, full production in-house
- Other companies: multi-step global supply chains
- Tilda: "I can receive the information very easy and very quick"
- Long supply chains struggle with data procurement

**Market Access Enforcement**:
- Not voluntaryâ€”mandatory for EU sales
- Transparent supply chains = easier compliance
- Opaque supply chains = expensive, difficult
- "It's easier for the good guys to do it"

**Quote**:
> "Not having control is expensive. Once you have control, it's easier to cost cut."
> â€” Gisle Mariani Mardal

---

themes.title: COLLECTIVISM VS. INDIVIDUALISM
themes.description:
**The Fundamental Divide**:
- **Nordic societies**: Individualistic
- **Greenlandic society**: Collectivistic
- Different approaches to resources, sharing, community

**Circular Economy Requirements**:
- Sharing resources
- Collaborative consumption
- Collective ownership models
- Knowledge sharing
- Community benefit over individual profit

**The Challenge**:
- All circular values = collectivist values
- Individualistic societies resist sharing
- Cultural shift required, not just technical
- Nordics must "practice being more collectivistic"

**Lise Lotte's Wisdom**:
> "We do have two ears and one mouth, so I really would like that we listen. While we share, we listen as well."

**The Imperative**:
- Nordics have expertise (technology, finance, policy)
- Arctic communities have wisdom (tradition, place-based practices)
- Both must share AND listen
- Knowledge transfer must be bidirectional

**Quote**:
> "One of the key differences between the Greenlandic society and the Nordic society is that the Nordic societies are individualistic and the Greenlandic is collectivistic."
> â€” Lise Lotte (via Frederik)

---

themes.title: KNOWLEDGE + MATERIALS + COMMUNITY = ZERO WASTE
themes.description:
**Lise Lotte's Synthesis**:
> "Nothing or less waste is possible when knowledge and materials and community are interconnected."

**The Three Elements**:
1. **Knowledge**: How to work materials, make, repair, use
2. **Materials**: Local, renewable, appropriate to place
3. **Community**: Shared values, reciprocal relationships, collective benefit

**When Disconnected (Linear Economy)**:
- Knowledge fragmented across designer/factory/seller/repairer
- Materials from anonymous global supply chains
- Community = isolated consumers
- **Result**: Waste inevitable

**When Integrated (Greenlandic Model)**:
- Knowledge embedded in makers who know customers
- Materials from known local sources
- Community benefits collectively
- **Result**: Waste impossible

**What Already Exists**:
> "We have the knowledge, we have the traditions, we have the business, we have the society, so we have a lot of the elements. Maybe it's just a kind of labeling the story."
> â€” Lise Lotte

**The DPP Role**:
- Not creating something new
- Making visible what has always existed
- "Labeling the story"
- Encoding ancient wisdom in QR codes

themes.title: PLACE ECONOMY PRINCIPLES
themes.description:
**Theory of Economic Development of Place**:
- The language is economy and numbers to describe holistic value
- Each value-creating link affects nature, human, and society
- Economic consequence of awareness drives sustainability economies
- Triangulate place + approach + topic for concrete value propositions

**Life of Place Framework**:
- Life of place = city life, village life, neighborhood life = life of planet
- Human activity on location defines economic description
- Quality of life must be defined by individuals
- Time and place together constitute experience

**Dynamic Value Creation**:
- Dynamics of place = dynamics of values in market and society
- Activity is the value of place
- Values of place are the qualities of place
- Qualities generate attractivity, which defines identity
- Identity determines quality of life

**Core Insight**:
> "You need to understand the human activity, and then the content is key. Communication and content is key, where culture is key to understand in a place-based approach with contextual and cultural understanding. If you don't bring that into the proposition, you're losing the value proposition."

---

themes.title: RIGA'S CIRCULAR TRANSFORMATION
themes.description:
**EU Mission Achievement**:
- One of 100 climate neutral and smart cities (EU mission label)
- Vision: modern driving force for circular economy innovations
- "Circular economy lab within the country"
- Source of inspiration for other cities and communities

**Eight Thematic Areas**:
- Waste management
- Renewable energy
- Mobility and transport
- Culture and business
- (Plus four additional areas)

**Three Work Directions**:

1. **Citizen Engagement**
   - Get back to basics: household separation, daily life reuse
   - Urban environments have forgotten circular practices
   - Make circularity accessible in daily life

2. **Municipality Resources**
   - Embed circularity in procurement guidelines and principles
   - Material bank for departments to share assets and inventory
   - Internal circular economy within municipal operations

3. **Circular Businesses**
   - Not funding, but moderating, stimulating, influencing
   - Networking and community building
   - Gather like-minded businesses for synergies

**Practical Examples**:
- Circular construction guidelines (used in procurement)
- Real estate transformation pre-study (using circular principles)
- Urban resource center (repair + community center, EU good practice database)
- Student design competitions for community spaces
- School circular economy competitions (2nd year)
- Library garden with circular principles (opening spring 2025)
- First Latvian Circular Economy Forum: 108 speakers, 34 sessions

**Funding Model**:
- Not from public funding primarily
- Attracting EU funds, sponsors, and grants
- Strategic resource assembly

---

themes.title: CESIS BIOREGION: FIRST IN THE BALTICS
themes.description:
**Context and Challenges**:
- Vidzeme region: beautiful landscape, forests, meadows, clean air
- Deep sense of community, strong cultural traditions
- But: sparse population, aging demographic, limited economic scale
- Research/innovation concentrated in capital (Riga)

**Key Learning**:
> "We cannot excel in every area being all alone. By working together small regions can achieve more than they could ever do in isolation."

**Bioregion Definition**:
- NOT an administrative unit
- Geographic and cultural space
- Public authorities, farmers, tourism operators, businesses, citizens
- Agree to manage local resources sustainably
- Based on ecological principles and shared responsibility

**Memorandum of Goodwill**:
- Crafted over one year, every word agreed by stakeholders
- 13 institutions: public, private, NGO, academic sectors
- A social contract and public commitment
- Six principles for working together
- Eight working directions/priority areas

**Eight Priority Areas**:
1. Increasing access to healthy, organic food
2. Developing short food supply chains
3. Managing natural capital through ecosystem services
4. Reducing waste
5. Accelerating energy efficiency and renewables
6. Providing sustainability education
7. Fostering authentic and nature-friendly tourism
8. (Eighth area in implementation details)

**Three Practical Examples**:

1. **Organic Food in Schools/Kindergartens**
   - Transform procurement system for local, organic ingredients
   - Replace anonymous supply chains
   - First organically certified school kitchen in Latvia (in progress)
   - Reduced emissions, healthier food, local economic value

2. **Circular Economy Center at Landfill**
   - Different concept: waste as resource
   - Developing new products from waste streams
   - Transformation not just disposal

3. **Financial Instruments & LEADER Integration**
   - Municipal grants for circular businesses
   - Integrated bioregion principles into LEADER program (EU rural funding)
   - Mainstreamed into LEADER funding strategies

**Philosophy**:
> "Strategic alliance based on shared values and really the aim to be in touch with the nature, to live in accordance with the nature, to respect the environment where we live."

---

themes.title: ARCTIC CONSTRUCTION PRINCIPLES
themes.description:
**Commercial Consultancy Perspective**:
- Unlike other panelists, represents commercial/consultancy role (not government)
- RambÃ¸ll Greenland - challenging public customers to push for circularity
- Through services, creating influence

**Traditional Arctic Survival Mindset**:
> "As a WIC, we can use almost anything. We essentially come from a place where how can I construct any piece of equipment or whatever in a robust way that I ensure that I'm also able to maintain? Because our survival essentially depends on it."

**Old Time vs. New Time**:
- Assumption: old time = industrialization, new time = what's ahead
- But: new time description = very, very old time in Greenlandic/Arctic sense
- Circular principles are pre-industrial Arctic practices
- "How do we make use of what we have without restricting future generations?"

**Remote Area Robust Design**:
- Often building where carpenter won't come by next week
- Important to have robust solutions
- High level of detail required
- Context varies enormously (Nuuk metropolis vs. 50-person settlement)

**Population Scale Reality**:
- Greenland: 0.00068% of world population
- Complete Arctic: 0.05% of world population
- Implication: Don't focus on innovating new high-tech materials
- Focus on utilizing applications of available materials
- Traditional practices provide insights for global circular economy

**Design for Disassembly - Personal Story**:
- Father born 1945 in small settlement
- When visiting birthplace decades later: "Where's the house?"
- Aunt's answer: "The house, we brought it."
- Traditional construction = design for disassembly
- Reusable in other settings as needs change

**Renovation Economics Example**:
- Lack of maintenance catching up now
- Positive: increased focus on maintenance, renovation, transformation
- Disko Bay housing blocks: strip to main construction, refurbish
- **About half the cost of new building**
- Structural parts = largest CO2 (especially concrete)
- Therefore: pursue renovation more

---

themes.title: NORDIC SUSTAINABLE CONSTRUCTION COLLABORATION
themes.description:
**2030 Vision**:
> "Within five years, the Nordic countries have this vision of being the most sustainable and integrated region in the world."

**Ministers' Declaration 2023**:
- Focus: "Recognize the potential in preserving and developing the existing building stock, and its contribution to reduced emissions"
- Political commitment to existing buildings over new construction

**2021-2024 Program**:
- Five work packages initially
- Key findings: Toolbox for Future-Proofed Construction
- Significant knowledge compilation

**LCA Calculation Requirements - Global Trend**:
- **Sweden**: First to mandate by law (calculate for new buildings)
- **Norway**: Followed shortly after
- **Denmark 2023**: Calculate + limit values for CO2 emissions per sqm
- **Iceland September 2024**: Calculation requirement introduced
- **Finland 2026**: Limit values coming
- **EU 2028**: Buildings >1,000 sqm must calculate
- **EU 2030**: All countries plan toward 2050 limits

**Harmonization Effort**:
- Worked together on how to calculate (many methods possible)
- Created common knowledge base
- Resulted in similar (not identical) regulations
- Could have been much more different

**Reused Products Policy Decision**:
- Question: What should reused products calculate for in LCA?
- Answer: More or less everyone wanted it **set to zero**
- Not real number (transport/processing has emissions)
- But provides political push and incentive
- Several countries calculate transport

**2024-2027 Continuation - Three Work Packages**:
1. **Climate/LCA** (Iceland lead): Making LCAs more efficient
2. **Circularity** (Denmark lead): Policy measures for existing buildings
3. **EU Coordination** (Sweden lead): Aligning with EU regulations

**Circularity Work Package Focus**:
- What policy measures can authorities use?
- Motivate better utilization of existing buildings

**Nordic Climate Forum for Construction** (held weeks before summit):
- All Nordic construction authorities
- EU Commission
- Key stakeholders across Nordic countries
- Presented: what they do to make it easier to use existing building stock
- Whole morning session, recordings and slides available online

**Policy Measures Catalogue** (initial mapping):
- Lifetime extension
- Minimize unnecessary demolition
- Remove barriers for efficient renovation
- Multiple use of square meters
- Incentives and tax instruments
- Design optimization
- Design for disassembly
- The procurement muscle
- Research, demonstration, and piloting

**Goal**: Create catalogue as inspiration for all Nordic countries and other stakeholders

**Educational Program**:
- For vocational teachers (carpenters, bricklayers)
- Often lack material on teaching sustainable construction
- Focus on reuse
- Available online in six Nordic languages (+ English)
- Freely available

---

themes.title: GREENLAND NATIONAL SUSTAINABILITY STRATEGY
themes.description:
**Formal Approval**: 2024

**Starting Point**:
- Political ambition + clear need for shared framework
- International reality: sustainability = competitive parameter (funding access)
- Greenlandic context: unique geographic, climatic, logistical conditions
- Small industry with strong sense of community
- Lot of trust among industry members

**Trust-Based Approach (No Mandatory Legislation)**:
> "We must succeed together. This also includes that we're not gonna, at least for now, put in some legislation concerning sustainability. We should be able to do this together and agree on all of those things."

- Holistic approach across entire sector
- Reliance on collective agreement, not top-down mandates
- Community trust enables consensus

**Three Guiding Principles**:
1. Sustainability (incl. CO2 reduction) = active, permanent element of all government construction projects
2. Create healthy, high-quality buildings benefiting society and users for future generations
3. Shared understanding of sustainability established across the sector

**Purpose**:
- Launch sector-wide dialogue for future direction
- Support more sustainable development in practice
- "In practice in Greenland is sometimes a bit challenging"
- Create common foundation for entire industry to build together

**Vision**:
- Construction sector operates with consideration for future generations
- **"The needs of the present must be met without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs"**
- Must: develop sustainable/innovative solutions
- Must: contribute to growth throughout country
- Must: reflect Greenland's culture and support local communities
- Must: contribute to better climate and environment
- Must: take global responsibility and participate in global developments

"It's a very strong vision for a small industry"

**Six Goals** (intentionally limited):
1. Government (as public developer) actively contributes through holistic approach
2. Sector establishes joint forum for dialogue and cooperation
3. Develop systematic methods/tools to measure sustainability and emissions
4. Determine environmental/climate impact, set targets, reduce emissions
5. Jointly define objectives and initiatives for sustainable constructions
6. (Sixth implied in overall implementation)

> "It's not many goals, which is also our purpose. It should be goals that we can actually meet."

**Seven Concrete Initiatives**:
1. Principles for sustainability
2. Prioritization of art and architecture in government projects
3. Development of national DGNB system (certification)
4. Development of shared LCA methodology
5. Establishment of Council for Sustainability within construction sector
6. Preparation of CO2 emissions action plan
7. (Seventh related to monitoring/communication)

**Implementation Progress**:
- **DGNB system**: Well underway, December conference for final dialogue
- **Government approach**: Will use DGNB standard but NOT get certification
  - "It doesn't really give anything of value to us"
  - But needs to be in place for private projects
- **LCA methodology**: December presentation
- **Council for Sustainability**: Established 2023, held two meetings
  - Main discussion: how to get to CO2 action plan
  - **Challenge: "We don't have any data at the moment"**
  - Need to start somewhere, building baseline

---

themes.title: RETROFIT FIRST ECONOMICS
themes.description:
**London Regulatory Model**:
- 2020: Requirement to retrofit buildings first
- Completely changed city development scene
- Regulatory approach makes renovation default

**Oslo Transformation Projects**:
- Circular economy drives biggest sustainability city projects
- Office â†’ elderly home: "one of best practices in real estate development"
- Keep resources + create societal relevance
- Old factories â†’ vibrant communities
- Rural abandoned factories â†’ travel, leisure, innovation, production hubs
- Small municipality (1,700 people) elderly home transformation

**Economic Transformation Effect**:
> "When you transform the buildings and fill it with the new life, storage to life, you get a completely different economic perspective, and you increase the value of the property."

**Outcomes of Good Place Development**:
- Maintain nature value
- Take care of human value
- Create societal value

**Riga's Systematic Approach**:
- Pre-study before transformation
- Using all circularity principles
- Using all available materials within building
- Subsequent procurement based on circular criteria

**Greenland's 50% Cost Savings**:
- Disko Bay housing blocks
- Strip to main construction
- Refurbish for new life
- **About half the cost of building new**
- Structural parts = largest CO2 (especially concrete)
- Keeping structure dramatically reduces emissions

**Nordic Ministers' Recognition**:
- 2023 declaration emphasizes existing building stock potential
- Contribution to reduced emissions
- High-level political backing

**Compounding Benefits**:
- Economic: 50% cost savings
- Environmental: Dramatically lower CO2
- Social: Neighborhood character maintained
- Cultural: Architectural heritage preserved
- Speed: Often faster than new construction
- Risk: Lower uncertainty

---

themes.title: CIRCULAR PROCUREMENT LEVERAGE
themes.description:
**Riga's Multi-Faceted Approach**:

1. **Circular Construction Guidelines**
   - Developed with construction community
   - Embedded in procurement practices
   - Circular requirements from the start

2. **Material Banks**
   - Municipality departments share assets/inventory
   - Internal circular economy
   - Reduces redundant purchasing

3. **Real Estate Transformation Procurement**
   - Pre-study informs actual procurement
   - Circular principles embedded
   - Available materials maximized

4. **Urban Resource Center**
   - Circular design from beginning
   - EU good practice database case
   - Repair + community center model

**Cesis's Organic Food Procurement**:
- Transform school/kindergarten procurement
- Local, organic ingredients prioritized
- Replace anonymous supply chains
- Reduce emissions, healthier food, local value retention
- First organically certified school kitchen (Latvia) in progress

**Essential Role of Circular Criteria in Tenders**:
- Not nice-to-have add-on
- Structural requirement
- Shapes what suppliers offer

**Why Procurement Matters**:
1. Creates demand justifying supplier investment
2. Sets standards private sector follows
3. Demonstrates feasibility at scale
4. Builds circular supply chains
5. Establishes viable price benchmarks

**The Procurement Muscle**:
- Municipalities and governments hold enormous market power
- Strategic use shapes markets
- Not just purchasing - market shaping

---

themes.title: URBAN-RURAL VALUE SYMBIOSIS
themes.description:
**Urban Learning from Rural**:
- Cesis bioregion: memorandum of goodwill model adaptable to urban
- Integration with existing funding (LEADER)
- Short food supply chains and local production
- Stakeholder-driven, place-based approach

- Arctic practices: robust design, design for disassembly, maintenance-first
- Relevant as craftspeople become scarcer in cities
- Supply chains more fragile everywhere

**Rural Learning from Urban**:
- Riga's urban resource centers: repair + community model works in villages
- Digital Product Passports and LCA at city scale
- Create transparency benefiting rural producers
- Lower transport emissions become visible and valued

- Circular procurement guidelines from cities
- Adaptable by smaller municipalities with less capacity

**Bidirectional Knowledge Flows**:
- **Urban â†’ Rural**: Infrastructure standards, digital systems, regulatory frameworks, market access
- **Rural â†’ Urban**: Traditional knowledge, place-based practices, community trust, ecosystem awareness
- Neither superior, both necessary

**Scale-Appropriate Applications**:
- Riga: material bank at city scale with multiple departments
- Cesis: bioregion at regional scale across four municipalities
- Greenland: 38 outposts, sometimes "three people and a freezer" at settlement scale
- Principles consistent, implementation varies by place/population/infrastructure

**Locally-Rooted-Globally-Connected**:
- Royal Greenland's 38 outposts example
- "Even the smallest settlements have global market reach"
- Not local OR global, but both integrated
- Small communities maintain lifeways + participate in global value chains
- Cities maintain innovation capacity + learn from rural wisdom

---

themes.title: TRUST AND COMMUNITY AS FOUNDATION
themes.description:
**Holthe's Core Principle**:
> "For the most important thing you have to build when you build places is trust. If you don't have trust, you don't manage to create any good place. And you need to make that into the transparent structures of structure."

**Greenland's Trust-Based Strategy**:
- No mandatory legislation (yet)
- Collective agreement through community trust
- "We should be able to do this together"
- Strong sense of community in small industry
- Trust between all working in industry

**Cesis's Memorandum of Goodwill**:
- One year to craft, every word agreed
- 13 diverse institutions sign on voluntarily
- Social contract, not regulatory requirement
- Public commitment to create cleaner, healthier, circular region

**Riga's Moderator Role**:
- Not funding, but stimulating and influencing
- Build trust through networking
- Convener and catalyst, not controller

**Why Trust Matters**:
- Enables risk-taking
- Facilitates experimentation
- Encourages knowledge-sharing
- Supports collaboration
- All essential for circular transitions

**Communication and Culture**:
> "Communication and content is key, where culture is key to understand in a place-based approach with contextual and cultural understanding. If you don't bring that into the proposition, you're losing the value proposition." â€” Einar Kleppe Holthe

- Cookie-cutter programs fail without cultural respect
- Context and communication in locally meaningful ways
- Culture shapes behavior more than regulation

**Sense of Belonging**:
- Quality and flexibility of proposition
- Relevance of meaning and place
- Long-term sustainable value proposition
- Accessibility and transparency of market dynamics
- Sense of belonging and trust = must build these

---
